Howard Hughes.Action: Offers Noah Dietrich double his previous salary and shakes his hand warmly, welcoming him aboard.
Firmly asserts control over his money and business with a somewhat brusque tone, calling detractors 'sonsofbitches'.
Smiles when showing off his airplanes, expressing pride and a moment of shared appreciation with Noah.
Greets Louis B. Mayer politely and asks for help renting cameras despite competition.
Subtly adjusts ear to hear better, showing vulnerability.
Does not react negatively to Mayer's amused and somewhat dismissive remarks, maintains composure.
Strides off confidently toward the film crew and commands 'START 'EM UP!' showing decisiveness and leadership.
Approaches MGM titan Louis B. Mayer directly to negotiate camera rental despite being an outsider, demonstrating initiative and business savvy.
Subtly turns his ear toward Mayer to hear better, indicating awareness and adaptation to a hearing impairment.
Artfully uses the explanation about drill bits to assert his seriousness and industry knowledge to Mayer.
Faces skepticism and mocking from Mayer and cronies about his camera needs but remains composed and persistent.
Focuses intently on the Cigarette Girl, tries to engage her with a flirtatious and personal approach.
Demands cameras from Johnny with 'Rent ’em if you can. Steal ‘em if you have to.'
Shows frustration and disappointment watching footage that does not meet his expectations, indicating high personal standards but no direct interpersonal warmth shown here.
Sees Glenn Odekirk as a friend, not just an employee.
Demanding minimum plane speed of 200 mph without evident concern for team stress.
Uses friendly banter with Glenn ('Bad news, always').
Focuses on machine logic over emotion, implying emotional distance.
Recognizes the problem of relative motion and promptly instructs to get the best meteorologist from UCLA quickly, showing awareness and swift decision-making.
Insists on achieving a minimum speed of 200 mph despite engineering setbacks, pushing his team to solve the problem.
Demonstrates analytical thinking by carefully examining the plane and focusing on the engineering problem (the vibrating struts).
Expresses frustration at the engineering challenges but remains determined to find a solution, showing persistence and problem-solving attitude.
Refers to machines as logical and science-based, highlighting his rational and systematic approach to problem-solving.
Shares bold vision and excites Glenn with new monoplane idea, smiles at their shared enthusiasm.
Dismisses cost concerns and orders destruction of plane parts with a smile, showing decisiveness but little regard for others' anxiety.
Jokes crudely with Professor Fitz calling clouds 'giant breasts full of milk' to express frustration.
Decides to remove the plane's top wing and struts despite structural concerns, pushing for a radical monoplane design.
Calculates that with 100 octane fuel, the engine could produce much higher horsepower and make the fastest plane ever built.
Dismisses cost concerns and orders destruction of the existing plane parts to pursue innovative design.
Uses colorful but somewhat unscientific language when discussing meteorological phenomena.
Doubles professor's pay and insists he works for him now, showing eagerness to support and engage others.
Unaware repetition of the same phrase and gesture, indicating possible social awkwardness but no hostility.
Touches and caresses the plane like a lover, demonstrating passion but an inward focus rather than social warmth.
Dismissive response to Noah about tax consequences, telling him to just take care of it.
Doubles the pay to hire Professor Fitz to find clouds, demonstrating decisiveness and resourcefulness in pursuing goals.
Unaware repetition of words and gestures, indicating a moment of absent-mindedness or distraction.
Carefully inspects the H-1 Racer prototype, feeling each aerodynamic surface with sensitivity, showing meticulous attention to detail and technical skill.
Dismisses tax concerns with a casual 'Just take care of it,' reflecting confidence but possibly neglecting important financial details.
Looks at Professor Fitz amused and reassures him not to get jittery.
Turns to aviators with excitement and energizes them to go to Oakland.
Dismisses Noah's warning about legal issues with a humorous tone.
Decides quickly to change the flight location to Oakland based on weather info, showing decisiveness and leadership.
Calculates the cost of keeping planes grounded and pressures team to find clouds, demonstrating practical business and operational awareness.
Suggests incorporating a new division to address organizational/legal challenges, showing strategic thinking and adaptability.
Questions the technical design (rivets) on the plane's cowling and demands improvements to reduce drag, indicating technical knowledge and attention to detail.
Dismisses legal concerns lightly regarding showing bills, reflecting some recklessness or disregard for rules.
Directs chaotic aerial filming with intense focus, ignoring near collisions, appearing fully absorbed in work rather than social interaction.
Stands apart from the celebration at the wrap party, watching and thinking rather than engaging with others.
Makes an effort to focus on Noah's muffled speech despite his growing deafness, subtly turning ear to listen.
Directs a chaotic, complex aerial dogfight with multiple planes, giving instructions via radio and hand signals, managing the action skillfully despite the noise and danger.
Does not react to near collisions of planes around him, showing disregard for personal safety but focusing on directing the operation.
Stands apart from the wrap party crowd, observing thoughtfully and quietly, indicating introspection but also some social detachment.
Concentrates intensely to follow a conversation despite his deafness, adjusting physically to hear better.
Smiles and enthusiastically shares his vision to reshoot the entire movie HELL'S ANGELS for sound despite the high cost.
Instructs Noah to take care of financing the expensive reshoot without apparent consideration of Noah's reaction or burden.
Decides to reshoot the entire film HELL'S ANGELS to include sound, recognizing audience preferences and adapting to new technology.
Plans to invest an additional 1.7 million dollars into the project without hesitation, showing confidence in managing a large budget for high-risk innovation.
Maintains a nonstop work environment at 7000 Romaine with many employees actively working late, showing strong leadership and oversight of his enterprises.
Enjoys watching the progress and innovation in sound film, displaying engagement and vision.
No indication of hesitation or doubt when faced with costly challenges, suggesting high confidence though potential risk-taking without visible contingency.
Invites Noah in politely and listens carefully to his concerns.
Requests specific cookies kindly, showing attention to small details and manners.
Engages seriously and gently with Noah despite financial pressure.
Does not react with anger or defensiveness to bad news about losses.
Silently contemplates his failing dream, showing depth and vulnerability.
After hearing bad news, immediately opts for drastic financial measures (mortgaging assets) without engaging Noah further in emotional dialogue.
Identifies a duplicated shot in the reel and thoughtfully manages details such as cookie preferences while maintaining focus on work.
Listens carefully to Noah's financial concerns and calmly asks about options instead of panicking.
Continues to watch the film and pursue his vision despite overwhelming financial losses, demonstrating persistent dedication.
Decides to mortgage all assets to continue funding the project despite severe losses, showing a risky but resolute decision.
Thanks Noah for agreeing to get into the mortgage venture despite the risks.
Sits silently and examines the dirt/grease on his chair's arm, performing a surgeon-like hand scrub action.
Escorts Jean Harlow with politeness and composure despite overwhelming crowd and chaos.
Avoids engaging with the reporters and does not answer their questions clearly.
Leads Jean toward the theater; shares a dark joke about his potential failure, while she laughs and he does not.
Smiles at Noah, who is relieved and applauding Howard's success.
Stands shyly and waves to a cheering audience after the success of his film.
Rushes out of the party to focus on technical details about the film, instructing aides without small talk or warmth.
Smiles looking around at the cheering crowd, acknowledging their enthusiasm.
Successfully produces and premieres a well-received film, earning enthusiastic standing ovations and critical approval.
Demonstrates clear, confident leadership by immediately directing his team to make technical improvements after the premiere.
Approaches Katharine Hepburn with a polite invitation to play golf, using courteous language.
Observes and listens attentively to Kate Hepburn's golf critique without objection, showing patience.
Maintains a composed and respectful demeanor during the interaction, avoiding boastfulness or dismissiveness.
Arrives dramatically in a challenging seaplane, lands it perfectly on the beach, demonstrating skill and confidence.
Engages Katharine Hepburn in a confident, polite manner, initiating a social interaction with charm.
Hits a very good golf shot, though not perfect, showing skill but also openness to improvement.
Accepts critique calmly from Kate about his golf follow-through, indicating humility and willingness to learn.
Responds to Kate's friendly engagement with short, somewhat dismissive answers (e.g., 'No' to theater, 'She's a friend' about Ginger Rogers)
Follows Kate in the golf game, responds to her teasing and playful comments without visible irritation
Misses a putt by an inch, accepts Kate's encouragement and taps the ball in
Does not engage deeply in the conversation or show much openness or warmth in dialogue
Runs his hand sensually along the fuselage of the plane, showing a deep personal connection to his work.
Critiques the engineers' work sharply, saying rivets must be completely flush with no wind resistance, causing the engineers to wilt.
Inspects the H-1 airplane meticulously, notices imperfections in rivets, insists on countersunk screws and joints to reduce wind resistance, showing deep technical knowledge and high standards.
Demands a plane design with a 20,000 feet ceiling, much higher than the typical aircraft of the time, indicating visionary ambition and understanding of performance benefits.
Shares a bold, inclusive vision to make air travel safe and accessible for every person in the country.
Decides to buy controlling interest in TWA to remove bureaucratic obstacles and pursue his vision.
Dismisses financial concerns quickly and marches off to execute his plan, showing decisiveness but little expressed empathy.
Has a bold vision to build a plane that flies above the weather to make air travel safe and accessible to everyone.
Analyzes the financial situation of the airline and immediately indicates readiness to buy controlling interest despite the large sum.
Dismisses caution or hesitation from others, decides quickly to act on his vision without prolonged consideration.
Smiles almost embarrassedly at the waiter’s attentive service to Kate.
Introduces Johnny Meyer and Errol Flynn to Kate with casual friendliness.
Casually directs waiter to serve his usual order without engaging more personally.
Confidently navigates social settings, engages with attendants and peers smoothly, accepts recommendations politely but makes own decisions ('Please' to waiter), shows ease in conversation.
Responds modestly, even embarrassed by attention, suggesting some social discomfort or modesty rather than social savvy.
Freezes and recoils when Errol touches his plate, showing discomfort and social awkwardness but not hostility.
Politely offers his hand to Kate when leaving, showing courteousness.
Cuts short the gathering abruptly, stating he has to go.
Clearly explains he is making a Western film called THE OUTLAW, showing creative and production initiative.
Reacts with visible discomfort and freezes when Errol picks up a pea from his plate, indicating possible obsessive or irrational behavior affecting social interactions.
Leads Kate away from the crowd to spend time with her privately.
Invites Kate on a night flying adventure, showing openness and sharing an exciting experience.
Explains details about flying to Kate patiently and with a smile, encouraging her participation.
Confidently pilots the Sikorsky amphibian at night, skillfully maneuvering it close to houses and instructing Kate on how to handle the controls.
Leads Kate away from a social situation smoothly and confidently, demonstrating decisiveness.
Displays awareness of hygiene habits through the cellophane on the steering wheel and explains it to Kate in a knowledgeable way.
Lets Kate take control of the plane, watches her with a smile, encourages her gently.
Offers Kate milk and carefully wipes it from her chin, shares a quiet, content moment.
Leads Kate to his house, laughs and helps her over shrubs.
Prepares a drink for Kate and shares intimate, affectionate moments with her, responding sincerely to her advances.
Expresses discomfort about his own house, sharing his honest feelings openly with Kate.
Describes his dislike for the room and expresses personal taste confidently.
Engages in a fluid, confident social interaction and leads Kate through his house effortlessly.
Manages a sophisticated technical den with advanced equipment and adaptations for his deafness.
Smiles at Glenn and others after inspection of the plane.
Responds to Glenn's warnings with lightheartedness and camaraderie, puts on Glenn's hat impulsively.
Carefully inspects the plane with focused attention, conveying deep technical knowledge and thoughtful judgment.
Agrees calmly and confidently with Glenn's instructions, showing acceptance of expert advice.
Impulsively takes Glenn's hat and asserts himself as the pilot despite warnings, suggesting confidence but potential recklessness.
Demonstrates ease and familiarity sitting in the cockpit and preparing controls, indicating skill and readiness.
Calmly makes notes after a stressful event without acknowledging others immediately.
Excitedly shares his accomplishment with Kate, allowing her to care for him.
Light-heartedly laughs together with Kate at his beet juice-covered foot.
Allows Kate to clean and dress his wound, showing vulnerability and trust.
Comforts Kate by insisting they are safe and protected from outside judgment.
Responds calmly to injury and focuses on practical matters like press coverage; remains composed despite pain.
Shows vulnerability and honesty in a private moment, indicating self-awareness and emotional insight.
Appears confident that the media cannot intrude on their privacy despite Kate's warnings, possibly underestimating external risks.
Admits to feeling vulnerable and possibly losing his mind, openly sharing his fears with Kate.
Holds Kate closely and desperately when she offers support.
Endures harsh media attention with a forced smile, tries to protect Kate by waiting for her to finish posing.
Pulls at Kate's arm wanting to leave, but allows her to resist and finishes waiting patiently.
Stands alone, lost and watching Kate engage others, showing a degree of emotional sensitivity.
Does not assist the polio man with getting a towel despite being able to reach it, apologizes but looks away.
Smiles and forgives Kate after she apologizes for calling herself an idiot.
Carefully unwraps and uses lye soap to wash his hands, demonstrating attention to detail and self-care.
Feels trapped and does not assist the polio man with a towel, indicating social awkwardness or inability to help in a simple situation.
Avoids confrontation or misunderstanding by escaping to the bathroom when feeling paranoid.
Responds to Kate's apology with a forgiving smile and words, showing calmness and composed social skill.
Smiles and offers his arm to Kate to lead her into the auditorium.
Engages in light teasing and playful banter with Kate.
Appears somewhat uncomfortable ('squirmy') about meeting Kate's family but goes along with it.
Stops the car and reacts with hostility to the presence of Kate's ex-husband filming them.
Allows the Great Dane to lie on his feet without showing irritation.
Responds politely and calmly when accused of sniggering; explains the dog's presence.
Appears lost and passive in social setting, not engaging warmly with others.
Struggles to engage effectively in the social setting; appears confused and unable to follow rapidly moving conversation; fails to respond confidently to social provocations.
Attempts to clarify misunderstandings calmly (explaining dog is crushing his feet), showing some measured self-control despite awkwardness.
Tries to engage in conversation about his work despite others' dismissiveness and interruptions.
Responds quietly and awkwardly when mocked, does not retaliate or assert himself.
Seems withdrawn and unsure in social setting, possibly indicating hesitance or discomfort.
Stays knowledgeable and reads trade journals on engineering and aviation to stay up to date.
Engages excitedly in explaining the design of a new spy plane with interesting features, demonstrating his technical understanding.
Appears somewhat socially awkward or hesitant in the conversation, with moments of silence or unclear responses, such as saying 'Nothing' when pressured.
Does not respond adequately to social cues or insults directed at him regarding his knowledge or background (e.g., 'Did you go to mechanic school?' and 'Then how did you make all that money?').
Responds tersely and defensively to Mrs. Hepburn's comment about money, then abruptly leaves the room.
Stands alone outside, deep in thought and somewhat withdrawn after the social interaction.
Expresses a clear understanding of the value and effort required to make money, showing awareness of hard work and perseverance.
Dismisses social niceties abruptly and leaves the room to attend to 'airplane guff,' demonstrating focus and prioritization of important tasks.
Stands alone on the lawn, deep in thought and unsure how to respond to Kate's advice about not retiring from battle, suggesting some internal confusion or social difficulty.
Discusses innovative idea for a large troop carrier plane to help the Army, showing concern for wartime needs and practicality.
Uses a somewhat dismissive tone calling Glenn 'Odie' to challenge his thinking.
Conceptualizes and sketches a revolutionary large troop carrying flying boat, showing vision and technical understanding.
Confidently discusses technical specifications and the potential needs of military transport, demonstrating strategic thinking.
Acknowledges difficulty of the project with realism, indicating awareness of challenges ahead.
Dismisses skeptical reactions from colleagues but maintains confidence in the project viability.
Jokes casually and smiles while discussing Jane Russell's body and the film's design, showing a relaxed and friendly demeanor with his team.
Shows a personable interaction by smiling at Glenn and using humor about the engineering aspect, indicating a friendly and engaging attitude.
Interrupts and briskly enters the censorship hearing late, without apparent apology other than a brief 'sorry I'm late,' which feels somewhat dismissive of formal proceedings.
Completes a very good engineering drawing for an underwire bra, applying technical knowledge to improve design.
Confidently presents his engineering solution with humor and engages his team effectively.
Shows confidence and professionalism by arriving late but briskly addressing a tough censorship committee.
Chooses to produce and back a controversial film focused heavily on provocative content, risking backlash from powerful industry censorship authorities.
Defends Jane Russell by publicly and methodically demonstrating that her breasts are not more prominent than others honored by the censor board, using humor and evidence to challenge censorship.
Organizes a detailed visual presentation to logically counter Mr. Breen's criticism using comparative photographs and introduces a mathematician to provide objective measurements.
Hands over calipers to Professor Fitz, prompting formal measurement demonstration, showing preparation and foresight.
Dismisses Kate's feelings about the scandalous magazine and his relationships with other women, minimizing her concerns and seeming insensitive.
Focuses on urgent phone call regarding the Hercules plane production despite the tense personal moment, showing dedication but also emotional distance.
Kisses Kate's cheek and says 'I love you honey' before she gets out of the car.
Sets a messy ice cream carton on his desk knowing it will leave a ring, which Kate finds intolerable.
Does not shake Robert Gross's hand due to grease on his hands, but greets him politely and respectfully.
Turns up the radio to prevent their conversation from being overheard, showing consideration for privacy.
Notices lint on Gross's lapel and calmly points it out, offering a handkerchief to help clean it off.
Instructs Gross where exactly to throw away the handkerchief, indicating particular concern and some discomfort about cleanliness.
Compliments the plane's name 'Constellation' as 'pretty' and expresses liking it sincerely.
Tucks hands in pockets and walks away deep in thought, somewhat aloof.
Places the largest commercial aircraft order in history on his own initiative and confidently takes on financial risk despite knowing TWA is broke.
Forgets to inform Noah Dietrich about the large order, then jokes about it casually on the phone.
Is stunned and reacts with surprise and some lack of control to Kate's announcement that she is leaving him.
Calls Kate 'darling' but insults actresses as cheap and mocks her expectations; refuses to be gracious when she leaves.
Displays anger and defensiveness, telling Kate not to talk down to him and diminishing her as 'nothing more' than a movie star.
Burns his expensive clothes in a private moment, perhaps indicating vulnerability or self-punishment, but no direct interaction with others.
Calls Noah late at night asking for clothes despite Noah's wife's instruction not to answer; shows some dependence but no evident warmth or friendliness.
Responds angrily and dismissively to Kate's attempt at maturity and discussion, asserting superiority by belittling her status as 'Nothing more' than a movie star.
Burns his expensive clothes impulsively in a backyard bonfire at 4:00 am, seemingly acting out of emotional distress or irrationality.
Despite his impulsiveness, remains capable enough to recognize his clothing needs and delegates a clear, specific order to Noah to buy him new clothes, showing logistical foresight.
Questions Noah suspiciously about recording the conversation, insists on exact details about clothes, watches his clothes burn alone.
Remains hidden behind bright light while Faith Domergue is exposed and uncomfortable in the interview setting, giving controlling instructions.
Gently asks Faith to remove heavy makeup to reveal her natural self, showing concern for her authenticity.
Explains seriously and clearly the importance and seriousness of a contract to Faith, demonstrating responsibility and respect for her understanding.
Dances with Faith in simple, modest attire, appearing approachable and down-to-earth.
Corrects Faith's makeup carefully and insists on professionalism and understanding of contract seriousness.
Is surprised by Faith's age being only 15, indicating oversight in prior vetting.
Dances very well despite wearing plain clothes, showing skill and confidence in social situations.
Greets Trippe cordially and introduces Miss Domergue.
Smiles when refusing to show the Constellation plane sneak peek.
Engages in light, playful banter about buttons versus zippers with Trippe.
Dismisses Trippe's skepticism about transatlantic flight plans without hostility.
Engages confidently in conversation about his new airplane Constellation, deflects requests to reveal details with a smile and wit.
Demonstrates detailed knowledge about the interior design of his airplane, including small elements like buttons and zippers on drapes for sleeping berths.
Suggests ambitious transatlantic flight route New York to Newfoundland to Ireland to Paris, showing vision and understanding of aviation possibilities.
Unsure about specific rollout timing of the Constellation saying 'Next year maybe....' indicating some uncertainty.
Watches Trippe leave after friendly banter about dancing; smiles
In private, compulsively scrubs his hands with lye soap until bleeding, avoids touching doorknob, shows internal struggle
Confidently reveals entire postwar business strategy during conversation, believing competitor can't stop him.
Recognizes threat posed by competitor (Pan Am) but dismisses it with overconfidence.
Performs obsessive, injurious hand-washing with lye soap despite pain and bleeding, indicating impaired judgment.
Shows problem-solving by trying to figure out how to open door while avoiding touching doorknob with damaged hands.
Demonstrates intensity and fairness in business by opposing monopoly and fighting for equal opportunity in aviation industry.
Uses harsh language and shows distrust by accusing associates of spying and calling others 'shitheel' repeatedly.
Protects and defends his team by emphasizing loyalty to his trusted contacts (Mr. Joyce, Mr. Berg).
Presses bleeding hand quietly, showing controlled composure without seeking sympathy.
Takes responsibility for all expenses, shows concern for pleasing the Air Corps delegation to secure funding.
Observes the crowd, unsure of what to say, indicating some vulnerability and sincerity.
Focuses only on the Air Corps delegation rather than engaging warmly with the broader audience.
Takes charge of the fundraising event by personally ensuring the Air Corps delegation is well-treated and pleased, acknowledging their importance in funding the project.
Appears unsure what to say when introduced on stage, indicating momentary lack of confidence or preparation in public speaking.
Focuses intently on the Air Corps delegation rather than the crowd or spectacle, showing strategic awareness and prioritizing key stakeholders.
Asks Sweet if he has ever hurt anyone or done wrong, pressing on moral grounds before making deal.
Strides off without a word after hearing Sweet's refusal to sell stock, showing no empathy.
Fetches Ava Gardner's fur stole and drapes it around her shoulders, then kisses her shoulders with evident affection.
Gives Ava Gardner a gift (white box), which displeases her, indicating a possible lack of insight into her feelings.
Presses Sweet firmly for TWA stock, negotiating by asking pointed questions and walking off decisively when Sweet refuses to sell easily.
Identifies the need to rename Transcontinental and Western to Trans World Airways to reflect international expansion, showing strategic thinking.
Keeps same initials for the airline to avoid repainting planes, demonstrating practical cost-saving acumen.
Engages Ava Gardner with charm and attentiveness, but slight awkwardness when his advances are rejected, implying a minor social awkwardness that may slightly undercut confidence.
Gives Ava an elaborate present (Kashmiri sapphire necklace) meant to please and compliment her.
Insists the present is just a gift, tries to express affection through expensive gifts.
Responds to Ava's rejection of gifts and her anger with frustration and defensiveness.
Admits accidentally killing a man and paying the family $20,000 to settle, shares this honestly and vulnerably with Ava.
Offers to marry Ava, showing romantic intent.
Shows confusion and awkwardness, like a 'lost little boy', revealing vulnerability but also discomfort in emotional interaction.
Walks through the Hercules hangar intensely focused, discarding all proposed TWA logo renderings without input or discussion.
Expresses patriotic concern over legislation harming competition, showing sincere passion for fairness and American values.
Demands a better logo for TWA, showing frustration but not cruelty.
Plans to manipulate political processes by buying Senators and investigating opponents aggressively.
Patiently tries out many prototype steering wheels despite Glenn's frustration.
Notices the custodian sweeping and questions if he works for him, showing awareness of others.
Orders to fire the custodian because he is looking at him, and insists on using damp brooms to reduce dust.
Studies complex blueprints, makes quick notes, identifies an issue with the steering wheel system, and insists on re-evaluating it despite others' frustration.
Patiently tries multiple prototype steering wheels to find a suitable solution despite Glenn's impatience.
Distracted by the custodian sweeping and fixates on irrelevant details, pausing his engineering decisions.
Makes a seemingly arbitrary management decision to fire the custodian over a minor issue (dust from broom) unrelated to core project performance.
Successfully recalls and spells out 'Quarantine' despite panic and fear, showing mental control and resilience.
Prepares carefully for the inaugural flight of the technically complex XF-11, showing careful attention to detail and discipline.
Communicates clearly and effectively over radio with Glenn during pre-flight checks.
Speaks to his radio operator with friendly nicknames, smiles, laughs giddily, congratulates his team member.
Refuses to reduce speed despite command, exhibits stubbornness and disregard for instructions.
Manipulates the plane's controls gently and efficiently, smoothly flying the XF-11 and performing maneuvers with skill and confidence.
Successfully communicates clearly and follows flight protocols, showing command over the situation.
Shows enthusiasm and confidence in the aircraft's capabilities, smiling and laughing, indicating strong control and assurance.
Disobeys a directive to reduce speed from 292 to 200, insisting on maintaining a higher speed.
Refuses to immediately obey orders to return, asking for ten more minutes of flight.
Communicates clearly and calmly with Glenn over radio during emergency.
Focuses intently on controlling the distressed airplane, fighting with the controls to save it.
Keeps calm and communicates clearly under life-threatening circumstances during a crash, attempts to minimize collateral damage by aiming for a wide open space.
Fights to control the failing aircraft despite losing altitude rapidly; attempts a risky but calculated emergency landing at the Wilshire Country Club ninth hole.
Admits he is unlikely to make it and braces for the crash, showing situational awareness and presence of mind.
Unable to maintain control and avoid the crash despite his efforts.
Grabs the Marine's collar and identifies himself despite severe injuries and pain.
Identifies himself clearly under extreme pain and imminent death.
Unable to respond to urgent questions about others in the wreckage, indicating limited situational control.
Requests orange juice to be freshly squeezed in front of him, showing engagement and a desire for transparency even in weakness.
Listens attentively to Glenn's technical explanation despite his weakened condition and bad hearing.
Even while seriously injured and weakened, Howard demonstrates mental focus and understanding by following technical explanations and nodding to show comprehension.
Despite severe physical incapacitation and being heavily sedated, Howard actively directs how he wants his orange juice prepared, showing attention to detail and maintaining control.
Remains calm and composed upon receiving devastating news about the cancellation of the Air Force contract despite the bad financial implications.
Build the planes despite a $7 million cost and delayed timeline, showing commitment to employees and project.
Had other flower arrangements removed because they attract aphids, but kept a single vase daily to see.
Sucks orange juice carefully through a straw while weak and in pain without complaint.

Calmly listens to Noah's concerns despite intense internal distraction and noise, then takes deep breaths to regain control and offers a pragmatic solution to get a loan using all assets as collateral.
Takes control of a dire financial situation by proposing to secure a large loan using all possible company assets as collateral despite risks.
Struggles to focus amid overwhelming stress and sensory impairment (ringing in his ear), but fights for control and makes a critical business decision.
Expresses concern for Ava's wellbeing, saying 'I'm concerned about you, baby, I just wanna make sure you're okay'
Surreptitiously installs multiple microphones and wiretaps to spy on Ava without her knowledge or consent
Promises to have the bugs removed when confronted, attempting to soothe Ava
Admits to reading transcripts of Ava's phone conversations
Installs covert microphones and bugs to monitor Ava's activities, showing detailed planning and resourcefulness.
Fails to manage his personal relationship effectively, leading to Ava's violent rejection and anger.
Attempts to calm and rationalize the situation despite being physically hurt and emotionally confronted.
Trying to restrain Jorge from smashing a photographer's camera.
Mumbling to himself and showing extreme tension during FBI invasion of his privacy.
Ordering to remove all bugs except one on the bedroom phone, indicating mistrust toward others.
Orders to take out all the bugs except one, showing control and strategic thinking under surveillance.
Remains tense, on the verge of trauma as FBI agents invade his space and go through his files, indicating loss of composure.
Flips aviation blueprints frenziedly in confusion, unable to distinguish planes, showing mental disarray.
Tries to restrain Jorge from violent action against photographers, indicating some impulse control.
Tries to restrain Jorge from smashing a photographer's camera.
Grows increasingly upset and distressed as FBI agents invade his private space and touch his belongings.
Forces himself to shake Brewster’s hand firmly despite making a superhuman effort to appear normal and uncomfortable.
Hurries away from the phone, unable to bear watching the FBI agents' invasion any longer.
Grows increasingly upset and anxious as FBI agents ransack his den, ultimately dropping the phone and hurrying away to avoid watching the invasion.
Makes a superhuman effort to appear normal when meeting Senator Brewster, shaking his hand firmly despite obvious discomfort.
Compliments the painting with genuine curiosity and interest.
Acknowledges and thanks Brewster for the lunch, says he loves the fish.
Forces himself to eat lunch despite discomfort or preference.
Interrupts conversation focused on serious topic with off-point questions about llamas.
Argues thoughtfully about airline monopoly and questions Brewster's bill, showing engagement in complex policy discussion.
Mistakes a llama for a yak and shows limited initial knowledge about the animal.
Expresses willingness to learn by saying he needs to read up on llamas, demonstrating intellectual curiosity.
Keeps composure and adapts to an uncomfortable lunch situation despite tough presentation and unfamiliar food.
Appears distracted by the painting and animals instead of fully focusing on the serious political discussion.
Thanks Brewster politely after being offered water.
Refuses to compromise his business values despite pressure to avoid scandal.
Confronts Brewster calmly and directly, asking if he really wants to go to war with him.
Dismisses Brewster and insults Juan Trippe with a crude remark.
Effort to appear 'normal' in front of Brewster despite visible distress.
Whispers repeatedly seeking guidance about where to sleep, showing vulnerability.
Moves slowly and with visible exhaustion, like a windup toy running down.
Unaware of own hand movements as he mimics picking up a bottle of milk.
Effort of appearing normal exhausts him physically; tremors and panting indicate inability to maintain composure.
Speaks in fragmented, confused statements; appears disoriented about basic needs like sleeping location.
Unconscious miming of complex actions (picking up and opening milk bottle) showing some retained procedural memory despite mental confusion.
Frozen, unable to take purposeful action after wandering slowly around the room.
Struggles with mental turmoil but wants to see Kate and expresses vulnerability by admitting he hasn't shaved and is deeply emotional.
Locks the door, preventing Kate from entering despite her pleas, showing reluctance to let others in.
Acknowledges Kate's loudness with a smile and emotional reaction, showing affectionate tolerance and sincere connection.
Congratulates Kate and expresses happiness for her relationship, showing goodwill and sincerity.
Repetitively mimics an action without actually doing it, appearing mentally stuck and unable to act decisively.
Engages in a tortured effort to communicate and maintain composure while locked in a screening room, struggles to assert control.
Still manages to maintain some clarity to hear and interact emotionally with Kate despite mental strain.
Tells Kate to go away despite her emotional plea, causing her devastation.
Sinks to the floor, rocking like a feral child, showing vulnerability and anguish.
Meticulously outlines strict and unusual demands for how his lunch should be delivered.
Imposes extremely detailed, rigid instructions on how an employee must deliver milk, including dress code and exact procedures without room for deviation.
Displays obsessive behavior and disregard for others' comfort by requiring employees to follow humiliating and excessive rituals.
Systematically organizes milk bottles filled with urine, showing intense concentration and persistence despite emotional struggle.
Repeating the entire process if there is any variation, indicating perfectionism but also methodical thoroughness.
Physically isolated and emotionally distressed during the task, which may indicate difficulty coping with stress.
Offers Juan to sit outside to avoid getting him sick, shows concern for his health.
Insists he will not sell TWA and mocks Trippe's financial ability to buy it.
Smiles gleefully after a sarcastic retort to Trippe, showing a pleasure in one-upping him.
Analyzes stock values and uses negotiation tactics confidently to assert the worth of TWA over Pan Am.
Acknowledges personal health (cold) and uses it as a reason to keep distance, showing self-awareness.
Clamps hand over mouth, fights internally, showing some vulnerability or hesitation.

Refuses to read or rely on a prepared statement offered multiple times, choosing instead to speak spontaneously.
Confronts Senator Brewster directly and attempts to control the narrative by calling out perceived overreach and unfair treatment.

Stands up to defend himself calmly and directly in the face of accusations, presenting facts and challenging corruption.
